sen.j: 大名（だいみょう）とは、大名主より転じた語。
sen.e: Daimyo is an expression that came from Daimyoshu.
Daimyo is an expression that came from Daimyoshu.
Daimyo is an expression that came from Daimyoshu.

sen.j: 大いに名のとどろく者のことを指す。
sen.e: It signifies a person whose name is very famous.
It signifies a person whose name is very famous.
It signifies a person whose name is very famous.

sen.j: 対（つい）になるのは小名である。
sen.e: As opposed to a Shomyo.
As opposed to a Shomyo.
As opposed to a Shomyo.

sen.j: もともと地方で勢力をふるう者のことを言った。
sen.e: It originally meant a person who wields influence in a region.
It originally meant a person who wields influence in a region.
It originally meant a person who wields influence in a region.

sen.j: そのうち、武家社会において、多くの所領や部下を所有する武士を意味する語となった。
sen.e: Later, in samurai society, it came to mean a warrior who has a lot of territory or subordinates.
Later, in samurai society, it came to mean a warrior who has a lot of territory or subordinates.
Later, in samurai society, it came to mean a warrior who has a lot of territory or subordinates.

sen.j: 室町時代には守護が領国支配を強め、守護大名となった。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period the Shugo strengthened their control over their assigned territories and became Shugo Daimyo.
In the Muromachi period the Shugo strengthened their control over their assigned territories and became Shugo Daimyo.
In the Muromachi period the Shugo strengthened their control over their assigned territories and became Shugo Daimyo.

sen.j: 戦国時代には、さらに強固な領国支配を確立した大身領主が現れ、大名分の国人や戦国大名と呼ばれている。
sen.e: In the Warring States period, Taishin Ryoshu (noble land owners) appeared who established even stronger control over their territories, and were called Daimyobun no Kokujin or Sengoku Daimyo.
In the Warring States period, Taishin Ryoshu (noble land owners) appeared who established even stronger control over their territories, and were called Daimyobun no Kokujin or Sengoku Daimyo.
sen.cmt: Ryoshuの後のスペースを調整。
sen.e: In the Warring States period, Taishin Ryoshu (noble land owners) appeared who established even stronger control over their territories, and were called Daimyobun no Kokujin or Sengoku Daimyo.

sen.j: 江戸時代には主に一万石以上の所領を江戸幕府から与えられた武家を指す言葉となった。
sen.e: In the Edo period the word specified a lord who was granted a territory of 10,000 koku or more from the Edo Shogunate.
In the Edo period the word specified a lord who was granted a territory of 10,000 koku or more from the Edo Shogunate.
In the Edo period the word specified a lord who was granted a territory of 10,000 koku or more from the Edo Shogunate.

sen.j: 一万石未満の武士のうち幕府直属の武士を直参という。
sen.e: Among warriors with less than 10,000 koku, those who belonged to the Shogunate were called Jikisan.
Among warriors with less than 10,000 koku, those who belonged to the Shogunate were called Jikisan.
Among warriors with less than 10,000 koku, those who belonged to the Shogunate were called Jikisan.

sen.j: なお、大名はその封建領主と性格が中国の諸侯と性格を共有することから、諸侯に準えて大名諸侯とも称された。
sen.e: Actually, because the feudal lords that were the Daimyo shared characteristics with Chinese lords (shoko), they were also called Daimyo Shoko.
Actually, because the feudal lords that were the Daimyo shared characteristics with Chinese lords (shoko), they were also called Daimyo Shoko.
In fact, because the feudal lords that were the Daimyo shared characteristics with Chinese lords (shoko), they were also called Daimyo Shoko.

sen.j: 本項では、主に江戸時代の近世大名について詳述する。
sen.e: In this article, I mostly explain about the Edo period, recent Daimyo.
In this article, I mostly explain about the Edo period, recent Daimyo.
This section describes the details of the Edo period, recent Daimyo.

sen.j: 守護大名および戦国大名については、当該項目を参照のこと。
sen.e: For Shugo Daimyo or Sengoku Daimyo, refer to the relevant articles.
For Shugo Daimyo or Sengoku Daimyo, refer to the relevant articles.

sen.j: 江戸時代の大名
sen.e: Edo Period Daimyo
Edo Period Daimyo
Edo Period Daimyo

sen.j: 江戸時代の大名は、家格・官位・石高・役職・伺候席によって序列が決められた。
sen.e: The rank of Edo period Daimyo was determined by family status, official rank, size of stipend, office, and service.
The rank of Edo period Daimyo was determined by family status, official rank, size of stipend, office, and service.
The rank of Edo period Daimyo was determined by family status, official rank, size of stipend, office, and service.

sen.j: まず、徳川将軍家との関係によって、一族の御家門(親藩、親藩大名)、主に関ヶ原の戦い以前に徳川家の家臣だった譜代大名、関ヶ原の戦い前後から家臣となった外様大名に分類される。
sen.e: First, depending on his connection to the Tokugawa Shogun family, related families (Shinpan, Shinpan Daimyo) were classified mainly as Fudai Daimyo (hereditary Daimyo) that were vassals of the Tokugawa family before the Battle of Sekigahara, and Tozama Daimyo (non-hereditary Daimyo) that became vassals around the time of the Battle of Sekigahara.
sen.cmt: 関ヶ原の戦い→http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/533058/Battle-of-Sekigahara 譜代大名→http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/149919/daimyo 外様大名→http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/601363/tozama-daimyo
sen.e: First, depending on his connection to the Tokugawa Shogun family, related families (Shinpan, Shinpan Daimyo) were classified mainly as Fudai Daimyo (hereditary Daimyo) that were vassals of the Tokugawa family before the Battle of Sekigahara, and Tozama Daimyo (non-hereditary Daimyo) that became vassals around the time of the Battle of Sekigahara.

First, depending on his connection to the Tokugawa Shogun family, related families (Shinpan, Shinpan Daimyo) were classified mainly as Fudai Daimyo (hereditary Daimyo) that were vassals of the Tokugawa family before the Battle of Sekigahara, and Tozama Daimyo (non-hereditary Daimyo) that became vassals around the time of the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.j: 初代将軍家康は将軍家が断絶した場合の血脈の維持や、全国の大名統制への監視、および幕府への補佐への意味も込めて、将軍家同様に徳川姓を名乗ることが許された徳川御三家を設置し、9男の徳川義直を尾張藩、10男の徳川頼宣を紀州藩、11男の徳川頼房を水戸藩に封じた。
sen.e: The first Shogun, Ieayasu, in order to maintain the bloodline in the event that the Shogun household died out, for supervision and control of the Daimyo nationwide, and for support of the Shogunate, established three branch households of the Tokugawa family that were allowed to use the Tokugawa name, and sent the 9th son, Yoshinao TOKUGAWA, to the Owari domain, 10th son Yorinobu TOKUGAWA to the Kishu domain, and 11th son Yorifusa TOKUGAWA to the Mito domain.

The first Shogun, Ieyasu, in order to maintain the bloodline in the event that the Shogun household died out, for supervision and control of the Daimyo nationwide, and for support of the Shogunate, established three branch households of the Tokugawa family that were allowed to use the Tokugawa name, and sent the ninth son, Yoshinao TOKUGAWA, to the Owari domain, the 10th son Yorinobu TOKUGAWA to the Kishu domain, and the 11th son Yorifusa TOKUGAWA to the Mito domain.

The first Shogun, Ieyasu, in order to maintain the bloodline in the event that the Shogun household died out, for supervision and control of the Daimyo nationwide, and for support of the Shogunate, established three branch households of the Tokugawa family that were allowed to use the Tokugawa name, and sent the ninth son, Yoshinao TOKUGAWA, to the Owari domain, the 10th son Yorinobu TOKUGAWA to the Kishu domain, and the 11th son Yorifusa TOKUGAWA to the Mito domain.

sen.j: さらに2代将軍徳川秀忠の兄で家康の2男である結城秀康を越前藩に封じたのをはじめ、全国に徳川一門の大名を置いた。
sen.e: Beginning with the elder brother of the 2nd Shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, and 2nd son of Ieyasu, Hideyasu YUKI, was sent to the Echizen domain, he placed Tokugawa family members as Daimyo all of the country.

Beginning with the elder brother of the 2nd Shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, and 2nd son of Ieyasu, Hideyasu YUKI, was sent to the Echizen domain, he placed Tokugawa family members as Daimyo all of the country.

Beginning with the elder brother of the second Shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, and second son of Ieyasu, Hideyasu YUKI, was sent to the Echizen domain, he placed Tokugawa family members as Daimyo all of the country.

sen.j: さらに歴代にわたり徳川将軍家の草創期を築いた譜代の家臣を譜代大名として置いて、幕府の軍事力を確保するとともに幕府の大老はじめ老中を中心とした重要な役職につけ、幕政を輔弼させた。
sen.e: Moreover, over the generations the hereditary vassals that supported the beginning of the Tokugawa Shogun family were placed as Fudai Daimyo, who secured the Shogunate's military power while serving as important officials from the Shogunate's chief minister to members of the council of elders, supported the Shogunate's government.

Moreover, over the generations the hereditary vassals that supported the beginning of the Tokugawa Shogun family were placed as Fudai Daimyo, who secured the Shogunate's military power while serving as important officials from the Shogunate's chief minister to members of the council of elders, supported the Shogunate's government.

Moreover, over the generations the hereditary vassals that supported the beginning of the Tokugawa Shogun family were placed as Fudai Daimyo, who secured the Shogunate's military power while serving as important officials from the Shogunate's chief minister to members of the council of elders, supported the Shogunate's government.

sen.j: 譜代大名は比較的石高は低く、譜代筆頭井伊氏の彦根藩が突出した35万石の大封を得ている他は鳥居氏や榊原氏、本多氏、小笠原氏などが比較的大封を得たが、江戸時代通して10万石以上を保った譜代大名は酒井氏、阿部氏、堀田氏、柳沢氏、戸田氏をはじめわずかである。
sen.e: The Fudai Daimyo had relatively small stipends, and aside from the prominent Fudai Daimyo in the Ii clan who received an unusual 350,000 koku in the Hikone domain, the Torii, Sakakibara, clans, Honda and Ogasawara clans received relatively large stipends, but throughout the Edo period only a few Fudai Daimyo maintained more than 10,000 koku, starting with the Sakai, Abe, Hotta, Yanagisawa, and Toda clans.

The Fudai Daimyo had relatively small stipends, and aside from the prominent Fudai Hitto in the Ii clan who received an unusual 350,000 koku in the Hikone domain, the Torii, Sakakibara, Honda and Ogasawara clans received relatively large stipends, but throughout the Edo period only a few Fudai Daimyo maintained more than 100.000 koku, starting with the Sakai, Abe, Hotta, Yanagisawa, and Toda clans.
sen.cmt: 譜代筆頭→Fudai Hitto 用語集よりkoku→kokuSakakibara, clans, Honda→Sakakibara, Honda10,000→100.000
sen.e: The Fudai Daimyo had relatively small stipends, and aside from the prominent Fudai Hitto in the Ii clan who received an unusual 350,000 koku in the Hikone domain, the Torii, Sakakibara, Honda and Ogasawara clans received relatively large stipends, but throughout the Edo period only a few Fudai Daimyo maintained more than 100.000 koku, starting with the Sakai, Abe, Hotta, Yanagisawa, and Toda clans.

sen.j: 権力と軍事力の分離のためにこのようになった。
sen.e: This was for the separation of influence and military power.
This was for the separation of influence and military power.
This was for the separation of influence and military power.

sen.j: 外様大名は関ヶ原以降、従属した大名であり、関ヶ原では徳川家に対抗した家も多い。
sen.e: The Tozama Daimyo were the Daimyo that joined after the Battle of Sekigahara, and many had opposed the Tokugawa at Sekigahara.
The Tozama Daimyo were the Daimyo that joined after the Battle of Sekigahara, and many had opposed the Tokugawa at Sekigahara.
The Tozama Daimyo were the Daimyo that joined after the Battle of Sekigahara, and many had opposed the Tokugawa at Sekigahara.

sen.j: それだけに幕府の警戒は強く、隠密による諜報活動を積極的に行い、不正や謀叛の恐れがある場合は、厳しく改易に処した。
sen.e: The Shogunate was very careful about that, actively carried out intelligence gathering activities using spies, and when they feared impropriety or insurrection, did not hesitate to revoke rank.
The Shogunate was very careful about that, actively carried out intelligence gathering activities using spies, and when they feared impropriety or insurrection, did not hesitate to revoke rank.
The Shogunate was very careful about that, actively carried out intelligence gathering activities using spies, and when they feared impropriety or insurrection, did not hesitate to revoke rank.

sen.j: 代表的な外様大名としては、加賀百万石として有名な前田氏の加賀藩、鎌倉時代以来の名家である島津氏の薩摩藩や伊達氏の仙台藩、黒田氏の福岡藩、浅野氏の広島藩、毛利氏の長州藩、上杉氏の米沢藩、鍋島氏の佐賀藩、細川氏の熊本藩、池田氏の岡山藩と鳥取藩、蜂須賀氏の徳島藩、土佐山内氏の土佐藩、佐竹氏の秋田藩といった国主が多い。
sen.e: Representative of the Tozama Daimyo were the Maeda clan of the Kaga Domain, famous for the million koku of Kaga, the Satsuma Domain of the Shimazu clan, a family famous from the Kamakura period, the Sendai Domain of the Date clan, the Fukuoka Domain of the Kuroda clan, the Hiroshima Domain of the Asano clan, the Choshu Domain of the Mori clan, the Yonezawa Domain of the Uesugi clan, the Saga Domain of the Nabeshima clan, the Kumamoto Domain of the Hosokawa clan, the Okayama and Tottori Domains of the Ikeda clan, the Tokushima Domain of the Hachisuka clan, the Tosa Domain of the Tosa Yamauchi clan, and the Akita Domain of the Satake clan.

Representative of the Tozama Daimyo were the Kaga Domain of the Maeda clan, famous for the million koku of Kaga, the Satsuma Domain of the Shimazu clan, a family famous from the Kamakura period, the Sendai Domain of the Date clan, the Fukuoka Domain of the Kuroda clan, the Hiroshima Domain of the Asano clan, the Choshu Domain of the Mori clan, the Yonezawa Domain of the Uesugi clan, the Saga Domain of the Nabeshima clan, the Kumamoto Domain of the Hosokawa clan, the Okayama and Tottori Domains of the Ikeda clan, the Tokushima Domain of the Hachisuka clan, the Tosa Domain of the Tosa Yamauchi clan, and the Akita Domain of the Satake clan.
sen.cmt: Maedaの前のスペースを調整。the Kaga Domainとthe Maeda clanを入れ替え。koku→koku
sen.e: Representative of the Tozama Daimyo were the Kaga Domain of the Maeda clan, famous for the million koku of Kaga, the Satsuma Domain of the Shimazu clan, a family famous from the Kamakura period, the Sendai Domain of the Date clan, the Fukuoka Domain of the Kuroda clan, the Hiroshima Domain of the Asano clan, the Choshu Domain of the Mori clan, the Yonezawa Domain of the Uesugi clan, the Saga Domain of the Nabeshima clan, the Kumamoto Domain of the Hosokawa clan, the Okayama and Tottori Domains of the Ikeda clan, the Tokushima Domain of the Hachisuka clan, the Tosa Domain of the Tosa Yamauchi clan, and the Akita Domain of the Satake clan.

sen.j: また、大名の格式として領地が1国以上またはそれに準ずる石高であるものを国主、城をもつものを城主大名（城主格）、城をもたないものを陣屋といって区別し、大名が江戸城に参勤した際に詰める部屋も格式に応じて分けられた。
sen.e: The status of a Daimyo was defined as Kokushu if their territory was one province or more, or an equivalent number of koku, as Joshu Daimyo (joshu class) if they had a castle, those without a castle were distinguished as Jinya, and the rooms that they occupied at Edo castle during their service there were differentiated based on the Daimyo's status.

The status of a Daimyo was defined as Kokushu if their territory was one province or more, or an equivalent number of koku, as Joshu Daimyo (joshu class) if they had a castle, those without a castle were distinguished as Jinya, and the rooms that they occupied at Edo castle during their service there were differentiated based on the Daimyo's status.
sen.cmt: Kokushu, koku, Joshu, Jinya→Kokushu, koku, Joshu, Jinya
sen.e: The status of a Daimyo was defined as Kokushu if their territory was one province or more, or an equivalent number of koku, as Joshu Daimyo (joshu class) if they had a castle, those without a castle were distinguished as Jinya, and the rooms that they occupied at Edo castle during their service there were differentiated based on the Daimyo's status.

sen.j: 詳しくは伺候席を参照のこと。
sen.e: Refer to Shikoseki for details.
Refer to Shikoseki for details.
Refer to Shikoseki for details.

sen.j: 大名は国持ち大名レベルはともかく、10万石単位の大名は封土の一円領有が殆ど許されず、大抵は城下周辺とまだらに領土を持った。
sen.e: Aside from Daimyo in charge of provinces, those with 10,000 koku were generally not allowed possession of a whole district, and usually held territory around the castle and in patches.
Aside from Daimyo in charge of provinces, those with 100,000 koku were generally not allowed possession of a whole district, and usually held territory around the castle and in patches.
Aside from Daimyo in charge of provinces, those with 100,000 koku were generally not allowed possession of a whole district, and usually held territory around the castle and in patches.

sen.j: 極端な場合には、一つの村を他の領主と分割支配した（相給）。
sen.e: In extreme cases, rule of a single village was divided between two land holders (aikyu).
In extreme cases, rule of a single village was divided between two land holders (aikyu).
In extreme cases, rule of a single village was divided between two land holders (aikyu).

sen.j: 大名は原則一万石以上であるが喜連川氏の喜連川藩は5000石であった。
sen.e: Daimyo, as a rule, had 10,000 koku or more, but the Kitsuregawa clan's Kitsuregawa domain was 5,000 koku.
Daimyo, as a rule, had 10,000 koku or more, but the Kitsuregawa clan's Kitsuregawa domain was 5,000 koku.
Daimyo, as a rule, had 10,000 koku or more, but the Kitsuregawa clan's Kitsuregawa domain was 5,000 koku.

sen.j: これは喜連川氏が足利氏の末裔であったからである。
sen.e: That was because the Kitsuregawa clan were descendants of the Ashikaga clan.
That was because the Kitsuregawa clan were descendants of the Ashikaga clan.
That was because the Kitsuregawa clan were descendants of the Ashikaga clan.

sen.j: 大名は武家諸法度や参勤交代の制度によって、幕府から統制を受けた。
sen.e: Daimyo were subject to control by the Shogunate through the Laws for the Military Houses and the sankin kotai (alternate attendance) system.
Daimyo were subject to control by the Shogunate through the Laws for the Military Houses and the sankin kotai (alternate attendance) system.
Daimyo were subject to control by the Shogunate through the Laws for the Military Houses and the sankin kotai (alternate attendance) system.

sen.j: その他、御手伝と称する課役や江戸時代末期には海岸防備を命ぜられることもあり、大名は常に経済的にも苦しかった。
sen.e: Other than that, there was a system of assignments called otetsudai, and at the end of the Edo period some were ordered to defend the coast, so the Daimyo were always in a difficult position financially.

Other than that, there was a system of assignments called otetsudai, and at the end of the Edo period some were ordered to defend the coast, so the Daimyo were always in a difficult position financially.

Other than that, there was a system of assignments called otetsudai, and at the end of the Edo period some were ordered to defend the coast, so the Daimyo were always in a difficult position financially.

sen.j: 大名にちなんだ言葉
sen.e: Words Associated with Daimyo
Words Associated with Daimyo
Words Associated with Daimyo

sen.j: 大名華族 華族のうち、大名諸侯出身のもの。
sen.e: Daimyo Kazoku - Among the nobility, those who had formerly been Daimyo.
Daimyo Kazoku - Among the nobility, those who had formerly been Daimyo.
Daimyo Kazoku - Among the nobility, those who had formerly been Daimyo.

sen.j: 大名屋敷 大名の屋敷。
sen.e: Daimyo Yashiki – A Daimyo's mansion.

sen.j: 江戸に何箇所か有し本邸を上屋敷、その他を下屋敷という。
sen.e: Out of several, the principle residence in Edo was called kamiyashiki, and the others shimoyashiki.
Out of several, the principle residence in Edo was called kamiyashiki, and the others shimoyashiki.
Out of several, the principle residence in Edo was called kamiyashiki, and the others shimoyashiki.

sen.j: 大名然 大名の様に鷹揚な様。
sen.e: Daimyozen – Generous like a Daimyo.
Daimyozen - Generous like a Daimyo.
Daimyozen - Generous like a Daimyo.

sen.j: 大名行列 大名が参勤交代の際に隊列を組んで移動する様。
sen.e: Daimyo Gyoretsu (Daimyo Procession) – The Daimyo moving in a file when changing beginning a term in Edo.
Daimyo Gyoretsu (Daimyo Procession) - The Daimyo moving in a file when changing beginning a term in Edo.

sen.j: また、要人を囲んで集団が移動する様を揶揄して用いることもある。
sen.e: Also used to refer jokingly to a group moving in a cluster around an important person.
Also used to refer jokingly to a group moving in a cluster around an important person.

sen.j: 大名火消 江戸幕府が諸大名に命じて作らせた江戸の消防部隊。
sen.e: Daimyo Hikeshi – Edo firefighter brigades that the Edo Shogunate ordered each Daimyo to create.
Daimyo Hikeshi - Edo firefighter brigades that the Edo Shogunate ordered each Daimyo to create.
Daimyo Hikeshi - Edo firefighter brigades that the Edo Shogunate ordered each Daimyo to create.

sen.j: 諸藩の藩士で構成。
sen.e: Made up of samurai from each domain.
Made up of samurai from each domain.
Made up of samurai from each domain.

sen.j: 大名貸し 大商人が蔵米を担保に大名に高利貸しをしたこと。
sen.e: Daimyogashi – When a major merchant lent money to a Daimyo at high interest with rice as collateral.
Daimyogashi - When a major merchant lent money to a Daimyo at high interest with rice as collateral.
Daimyogashi - When a major merchant lent money to a Daimyo at high interest with rice as collateral.

sen.j: 大名預け 幕府が罪人の管理を大名に任せること。
sen.e: Daimyoazuke – When the Shogunate entrusted management of criminals to a Daimyo.
Daimyoazuke - When the Shogunate entrusted management of criminals to a Daimyo.
Daimyoazuke - When the Shogunate entrusted management of criminals to a Daimyo.

sen.j: 大名普請 贅沢な普請。
sen.e: Daimyo Bushin – Extravagant construction.
Daimyo Bushin - Extravagant construction.
Daimyo Bushin - Extravagant construction.

sen.j: 大名旅行 贅沢な旅行。
sen.e: Daimyo Ryoko – Extravagant travel.
Daimyo Ryoko - Extravagant travel.

sen.j: 大名飛脚 大名が江戸と国許の連絡のために設けた飛脚のこと。
sen.e: Daimyo Hikyaku - A messenger that a Daimyo employed to communicate between Edo and the province.
Daimyo Hikyaku - A messenger that a Daimyo employed to communicate between Edo and the province.
sen.cmt: Aの前のスペースを調整。
sen.e: Daimyo Hikyaku - A messenger that a Daimyo employed to communicate between Edo and the province.

sen.j: 大名下ろし 中骨に身を多く残すようにして魚を三枚におろすこと。
sen.e: Daimyo Oroshi – Cutting a fish into three slices so that a lot of meat stays around the spine.
Daimyo Oroshi - Cutting a fish into three slices so that a lot of meat stays around the spine.
Daimyo Oroshi - Cutting a fish into three slices so that a lot of meat stays around the spine.

sen.j: 豪勢であることからいわれる。
sen.e: Comes from the fact that the practice is extravagant.
Comes from the fact that the practice is extravagant.
Comes from the fact that the practice is extravagant.

sen.j: 大名切り 魚や肉の身を大雑把に大きく切ること。
sen.e: Daimyogiri – Cutting meat or fish into rough chunks.
Daimyogiri - Cutting meat or fish into rough chunks.
Daimyogiri - Cutting meat or fish into rough chunks.

sen.j: 大名買い 売り手のいうままに購入すること。
sen.e: Daimyogai – Purchasing something just as the seller asks for.
Daimyogai - Purchasing something just as the seller asks for.
Daimyogai - Purchasing something just as the seller asks for.

sen.j: 大名椀 大きな椀。
sen.e: Daimyo Wan – A big bowl.
Daimyo Wan - A big bowl.
Daimyo Wan - A big bowl.

sen.j: 大名倹飩 主に大名の紋や船などが描かれた、漆絵がある器に入れて出された倹飩を指して言う。
sen.e: Daimyo Kendon – Refers to a Kendon that is taken in and out of a container that has a lacquer painting of a Daimyo's family crest or boat.
Daimyo Kendon - Refers to a Kendon that is taken in and out of a container that has a lacquer painting of a Daimyo's family crest or boat.
Daimyo Kendon - Refers to a Kendon that was served in a container that has a lacquer painting of a Daimyo's family crest or boat.

sen.j: 大名縞 細かい縦縞模様。
sen.e: Daimyojima – A design of thin, vertical pinstripes.
Daimyojima - A design of thin, vertical pinstripes.
Daimyojima - A design of thin, vertical pinstripes.

sen.j: 室町時代の辞書『節用集』には、「たいめい」・「だいみょう」の2音を載せ、前者は守護（大領主）、後者は銭持（富裕層）の意であるとした。
sen.e: The Muromachi period dictionary Setsuyoshu listed the 2 pronunciations "taimei" and "daimyo", the former meaning a Shugo (a major feudal lord), and the latter meaning a wealthy person (the wealthy class).

The Muromachi period dictionary Setsuyoshu listed the 2 pronunciations "taimei" and "daimyo," the former meaning a Shugo (a major feudal lord), and the latter meaning a wealthy person (the wealthy class).

The Muromachi period dictionary "Setsuyoshu" listed the two pronunciations 'taimei' and 'daimyo,' the former meaning a Shugo (a major feudal lord), and the latter meaning a wealthy person (the wealthy class).

sen.j: 戦国時代には音による意味の区別が薄れ、「たいめい」と呼ぶことが多かったとされる。
sen.e: In the Warring States period, the distinction by pronunciation weakened, and it is thought that "taimei" was common.
In the Warring States period, the distinction by pronunciation weakened, and it is thought that "taimei" was common.
In the Warring States period, the distinction by pronunciation weakened, and it is thought that 'taimei' was common.

sen.j: 17世紀初頭の日葡辞書にも「だいみょう」・「たいめい」の2音が掲載されているが、語義の区別は明確でなく、2音とも大領主としている。
sen.e: The Nippo Jisho (Japanese-Portuguese dictionary) from the beginning of the 17th century also listed the 2 pronunciations, "daimyo" and "taimei," but there was no clear distinction in meaning, and both were used for major feudal lords.

The Nippo Jisho (Japanese-Portuguese dictionary) from the beginning of the 17th century also listed the 2 pronunciations, "daimyo" and "taimei," but there was no clear distinction in meaning, and both were used for major feudal lords.

The Nippo Jisho (Japanese-Portuguese dictionary) from the beginning of the 17th century also listed the two pronunciations, 'daimyo' and 'taimei,' but there was no clear distinction in meaning, and both were used for major feudal lords.
sen.cmt: 17thのｔｈの上付き解除原文の「」にあわせ"を'に

sen.j: 「だいみょう」の音に定着したのは江戸時代に入ってからで、寛政期ごろには専ら「だいみょう」と称した。
sen.e: The pronunciation settled on "Daimyo" after the beginning of the Edo period, and by the Kansei era they were solely called "Daimyo."
The pronunciation settled on "Daimyo" after the beginning of the Edo period, and by the Kansei era they were solely called "Daimyo."
The pronunciation settled on 'Daimyo' after the beginning of the Edo period, and by the Kansei era they were solely called 'Daimyo.'
